instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BLK_EN: What is BLK_EN? This is a typo of BKL_EN When you see BLK_EN, assume they meant to type BKL_EN.
definitions.BLK_PWM: What is BLK_PWM? BLK_PWM is a typo of BKL_PWM. When you see BLK_PWM assume the poster meant to type BKL_PWM. BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No backlight.
threads.message:
Take a look at how the top layer is bubbling.

Is this worth repairing?



Issue seems to be that <SIGNAL>BLK_PWM</SIGNAL> is at 0.460v and <SIGNAL>BLK_EN</SIGNAL> is also at 0.460v.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No backlight.
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No backlight.
threads.message: Yes it is fixable... Maybe need to run some wires but it has a good chance...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No backlight.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> @ <CAPACITOR>C7704</CAPACITOR> with no screen cycles from 0.340 - 1v - 1.4v and back again.
Connect a screen and I get basically 0v.

I removed <CAPACITOR>C7704</CAPACITOR> because it looked yuck with no change.

<SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> should be around 3.4v right?

If I jump <CAPACITOR>C7704</CAPACITOR>::1 to 3.4v I get a backlight; so I'm onto it, just need to resolve <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No backlight.
threads.message: PWM can be in the 1.4-3V range. What have you done to fix? I would wipe the whole area, check traces and start fresh.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No backlight.
threads.message: I can tell the traces are corroded out just by looking. How do I run a jumper to PWM when it comes out of CPU?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No backlight.
threads.message: Remove <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and see what the diode mode readings are on both sides to determine if trace is really fucked.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No backlight.
threads.message:
You can mark this solved.

I ran a very short jumper wire to what was left of the test point next to <RESISTOR>R7704</RESISTOR> and backlight with brightness works again.
